introduction.p: An integral part of the modern understanding of geometry is the concept of congruence transformation, or simply symmetry. The symmetries of a geometric space preserve inherent properties of figures, such as distance, angle, and area. In his 1872 work called the Erlanger Programm,The German term Erlanger Programm (or Erlangen program in English) is named after the city Erlangen, where Klein worked at the university. Felix Klein unified the study of a wide variety of geometric spaces by overtly placing the group of congruence transformations as part of the structure of a geometry. The following is a version of Klein's definition of geometry.

statement.p: A geometrygeometry is a pair (X,G), where X is a set, called the (model) spacemodel space, and G is a group, called the group of congruence transformationscongruence transformations, that acts on X. Subsets of X are called figuresfigure. Figures F,F' are called congruentcongruent if there is an element g in G such that g(F)=F'. We write F\cong F'F \cong F' figure F is congruent to figure F' to denote that figures F,F' are congruent.

introduction.p: Note on terminology and notation: throughout this chapter on geometry, the term transformation will always mean a one-to-one and onto map of a space to itself. Given a geometry (X,G) with group action \phi\colon G\to \Perm(X), we will abuse notation and write g\colon X\to X to denote the map \phi(g)\colon X\to X for an element g in G. It is common usage to say the transformation g to mean the transformation \phi(g) of the space X.

aside.title: Instructor's comment on notation convention
aside.p: The definition of geometry given here as a pair (X,G) with the model space X listed first and the transformation group G listed second follows Henle .

statement.p: Show that congruence is an equivalence relation on the set of figures in a geometry.

aside.title: Instructor's solution for
aside.p: For symmetry, we have F=\Id F for all figures F. For reflexivity, if F'=gF, then F=g^{-1}F'. For transitivity, if F'=gF and F''=hF', then F''=hF'=h(gF)=(gh)F. Comment: This is almost the same exercise as showing that the in the same orbit relation coming from a group acting on a set is an equivalence relation. You could even point out that it is the same exercise, if you note that you need to consider the action G\to \Perm({\mathcal P}(X)) (that is, transformations acting on figures) that arises from the action G\to \Perm(X) of transformations acting on points.

ul.li: Planar Euclidean geometryEuclidean planar geometrygeometries, list ofEuclidean planar geometry . The model space for planar Euclidean geometry is the plane \R^2. The group of congruence transformations consists of translations, rotations, reflections, and their compositions. Specifically, Euclidean congruences are functions of the form {v}\to R{v}+{b}, where {v} \in \R^2, R is an element of the group of 2\times 2 orthogonal matrices, and {b}\in\R^2.

Spherical geometry.spherical geometrygeometries, list ofspherical geometry spherical geometry The model space for spherical geometry is the sphere S^2=\{(x,y,z)\in \R^3\colon x^2+y^2+z^2=1\}. The group of congruence transformations consists of rotations of the sphere and reflections across planes through the origin. Specifically, spherical congruences are functions of the form {v}\to R{v}, where {v} \in \R^3, |{v}|=1, and R is an element of the group of 3\times 3 orthogonal matrices.

Projective geometry.projective geometrygeometries, list ofprojective geometry
The model space for a projective geometry is projective space \Proj(V), where V is a vector space V (see in the previous chapter). The group of congruence transformations is the projective linear group PGL(V).

subsection.title: Planar geometries
subsection.p:
Much of this chapter on geometry is devoted to a family of planar geometries whose model spaces are the extended complex plane \hat{\C}=\C\cup\{\infty\} (described in section ) and some of its subsets. One of the properties shared by the congruence transformations in all of these planar geometries is conformality, or angle preservation. To say that a transformation T is conformalconformal transformation means that if two curves C_1 and C_2 make an oriented angle \theta at a point P of intersection, then the two image curves T(C_1) and T(C_2) also make the same oriented angle at the point T(P) of intersection (the angle made by two curves is the angle made by their tangents at the point of intersection). See . examines the conformal properties of the four basic types of complex functions summarized in .

subsection.title: Subgeometries and equivalent geometries

statement.p: We say that a geometry (X,G) is a subgeometrysubgeometry of a geometry (Y,H) if X is a subset of Y and G is a subgroup of H and the action of G on X is compatible with the action of H on Y in the sense that g\cdot x has the same value in both geometries (X,G) and (Y,H) for all g\in G, x\in X.

Geometries (X,G) and (Y,H) are equivalentequivalent geometries if there is a bijective map \mu\colon X\to Y such that every element of H has a conjugate transformation in G and every element of G has a conjugate transformation in H. In symbols:See the note on terminology at the beginning of this section: the equation \mu\circ g\circ \mu^{-1} = h below really means \mu\circ \phi(g)\circ \mu^{-1} = \psi(h), where \phi,\psi are the actions of G on X and H on Y, respectively.
for every g\in G, there is an h\in H such that \mu\circ g\circ \mu^{-1} = h, and
for every h\in H, there is a g\in G such that \mu^{-1}\circ h\circ \mu = g.
Equivalent geometries are said to be models of the same geometry.

subsection.p: Note on terminology: the term geometry is used to refer to a specific model as in definition , and also to refer to an equivalence class of geometries.This is similar to the situation for groups, where the term the cyclic group of order n can refer to additive group \Z_n, or the multiplicative group of nth complex roots of unity, or simply the isomorphism class of these groups.

exercise.title: Warm up exercises with the three example geometries

ol.li: Find the Euclidean congruence transformation that takes the triangle with vertices (2,0),(6,0),(6,3) to the triangle with vertices (0,-1),(0,-5),(3,-1).

Find all possible spherical congruences that take the three points (0,0,1),(0,0,-1),(1,0,0) to the three points (1,0,0),(-1,0,0),(0,1,0) (in that order). One of these is a rotation: find an axis and angle for that rotation.
Find the projective transformation in PGL(2,\C) that takes the three points [(1,1)],[(0,1)],[(1,0)] in \Proj(\C^2)to [(a,1)],[(b,1)],[(c,1)] (in that order).
Find formulas for the composition of two Euclidean transformations and the inverse of a Euclidean transformation.
Let d(P,Q) denote the distance between points P,Q in Euclidean geometry, and let T be a Euclidean congruence transformation. Show that d(T(P),T(Q))=d(P,Q).

li.p:
These are both 3-4-5 triangles. One way to map the first triangle to the second is the following sequence of transformations.
shift left 6 units: (x,y)\to (x-6,y)
rotate 90 degrees (counterclockwise): (x,y)\to (-y,x)
shift down 1 unit: (x,y)\to (x,y-1)
reflect across the y-axis: (x,y)\to (-x,y)
Putting all this together, we get (x,y)\to (y,x-7). This is the Euclidean transformation v\to Rv + b with R=\twotwo{0}{1}{1}{0} and b=(0,-7).

The input/output pairs (1,0,0)\to (0,1,0), (0,0,1)\to (1,0,0) determine the first and third columns of an orthogonal matrix, namely (0,1,0)^T,(1,0,0)^T. The middle column must then be (0,0,\pm 1)^T. The matrix with middle column (0,0, 1)^T has determinant 1, so it is the rotation. You can find the axis of rotation by finding an eigenvector. It would then take more work to find the angle of rotation. Here is a way to use quaternions to determine the axis and angle. One possible composition of rotations is R_{Y,\pi/2} followed by R_{X,\pi/2}. These rotations are realized by quaternions \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1+j), \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1+i), respectively. So the rotation we want is given by the quaternion \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1+i)\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1+j) =\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\left(\frac{i+j+k}{\sqrt{3}}\right)=\cos \frac{\pi}{3} + \sin \frac{\pi}{3}u
with u=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}(i+j+k). By , this is the rotation about (1,1,1) by 2\pi/3 radians.

ol.li: We need a two-by-two invertible matrix T such that T(1,0)= \alpha(c,1), T(0,1)=\beta(b,1) and T(1,1)= \gamma(a,1) for some \alpha,\beta,\gamma. The first two requirements are met by T=\twotwo{\alpha c}{\beta b}{\alpha}{\beta}. Solve the system T(1,1)=\gamma(a,1) leads to (\alpha,\beta)\propto (a-b,c-a). This leads to the projective transformation given by the matrix \twotwo{(a-b)c}{(c-a)b}{a-b}{c-a}.

Let T_1,T_2 be Euclidean transformations given by v\to R_1v+b_1 and v\to R_2v+b_2, respectively. The composition T_2(T_1(v))=R_2(R_1v+b_1)+ b_2=R_2R_1v + (R_2b_1+b_2) is indeed a Euclidean transformation. The identity element has R=\Id and b=(0,0). The inverse of v\to Rv+b is given by v\to R^{-1}v - R^{-1}b.
Let T be given by v\to Rv+b. We have d(T(P),T(Q))= |(RP+b)-(RQ+b)|=|R(P-Q)|=|P-Q|=d(P,Q) (the penultimate equality holds because orthogonal transformations preserve vector norm).

figure.caption: The angle between tangents to curves as a limit of secant approximations

introduction.p: The complex plane comes with a built-in measure of oriented angle. If u is a positive real number, v=0, and w\neq 0 is a complex number, the measure of the oriented angle \angle uvw is \arg w. More generally, if u,v,w are three complex numbers with v distinct from u and w, the measure of the oriented angle \angle uvw is \arg\left(\frac{w-v}{u-v}\right).

statement.p: Use the fact that rotations and translations are conformal to prove .
Use to prove that homotheties are conformal.

Now suppose two curves C_1,C_2 intersect at v, let u be a point on C_1 and let w be a point on C_2. If u and w are close to v, then \angle uvw is a secant approximation of an angle made by the tangents to C_1,C_2 at v. See . Now let p(t),q(s) be parameterizations of C_1,C_2, respectively, with p(0)=q(0)=v, and p(t_1)=u, q(s_1)=w for some t_1,s_1\gt 0. We can compute an angle made by the tangents to the curves by the following limit. \lim_{s\to 0^+,t\to 0^+} \arg\left(\frac{q(s)-v}{p(t)-v}\right) The value of limit is sensitive to the direction of the curve parameterizations and the sided-ness of the limits t\to 0^{\pm} or s\to 0^{\pm}. If the value of the limit is \theta for one set of choices for parameterizations and sided-ness, the limit for the other choices will be \theta or \theta \pm \pi. For a given pair of parameterizations p,q, draw a sketch to illustrate the four possible cases t\to 0^{\pm},s\to 0^{\pm}.
Use and to prove that inversion is conformal.

aside.title: Instructor's solution for
aside.p:
Let T be the transformation T(z)=e^{-i\arg(u-v)}(z-v). T is conformal because T is a composition of a rotation and a translation, so we have \angle uvw= \angle T(u)T(v)T(w). Since T(u) is on the positive real axis and T(u)=0, we have \angle T(u)T(v)T(w)\amp =\arg(T(w)) \amp =\arg(e^{-i\arg(u-v)}(w-v)) \amp =\arg(w-v)-\arg(u-v) \amp =\arg\left(\frac{w-v}{u-v}\right)
as desired.

statement.p: Show that the definition of equivalence of geometries actually defines an equivalence relation on geometries.

Let {\mathcal E}_1 denote the set of Euclidean congruence transformations given above in . Let {\mathcal E}_2 denote the set of complex functions that can be written as compositions of the following three types.
z\to e^{it}z for some t\in \R
z\to z+b for some b\in \C
z\to z^{\ast}
Show that the geometries (\R^2,{\mathcal E}_1) and (\C,{\mathcal E}_2) are equivalent.
Suppose that (X,G) and (Y,H) are equivalent geometries. Is it necessarily the case that G and H are isomorphic groups? If yes, give a proof. If no, give a counterexample.

aside.title: Instructor's solution for
aside.p: Let (X,G), (Y,H), and (Z,K) be geometries. Clearly (X,G) is equivalent to itself via the identity map on X. It is also easy to see that if \mu\colon X\to Y is a geometry equivalence map, then \mu^{-1}\colon Y\to X is also a geometry equivalence. It is also easy to see that if \mu\colon X\to Y and \nu\colon Y\to Z are geometry equivalence maps, then \nu\circ \mu\colon X\to Z is also a geometry equivalence map.

aside.title: Instructor's solution for
aside.p:
Let \mu\colon \R^2\to \C be the canonical identification \mu(x,y)=x+iy. All three of the types of generators for {\mathcal E}_2 are conjugate to elements of {\mathcal E}_1, as follows.
(\mu^{-1}\circ [z\to e^{itz}]\circ \mu) \amp = \left[v\to \twotwo{\cos t}{-\sin t}{\sin t}{\cos t}v\right]\in {\mathcal E}_1 (\mu^{-1} \circ [z\to z+b] \circ \mu) \amp= \left[v\to v+(\re(b),\im(b))\right]\in {\mathcal E}_1 (\mu^{-1} \circ [z\to z^\ast] \circ \mu) \amp= \left[(x,y)\to v+(x,-y))\right]\in {\mathcal E}_1
We can also read these conjugation relations in reverse.
(\mu^{-1}\circ \left[v\to \twotwo{\cos t}{-\sin t}{\sin t}{\cos t}v\right]\circ \mu) \amp = [z\to e^{itz}]\in {\mathcal E}_2 (\mu^{-1} \circ \left[v\to v+(\re(b),\im(b))\right] \circ \mu) \amp= [z\to z+b]\in {\mathcal E}_2 (\mu^{-1} \circ \left[(x,y)\to v+(x,-y))\right]\circ \mu) \amp= [z\to z^\ast]\in {\mathcal E}_2
Using the fact that O(2) is generated by matrices of the form \twotwo{\cos t}{-\sin t}{\sin t}{\cos t} and \twotwo{1}{0}{0}{-1}, we have shown that generators of {\mathcal E}_1 are conjugate to generators of {\mathcal E}_2, and vice-versa. It is easy to see that, because the conjugacy condition holds for generators, the conjugacy condition holds for all of {\mathcal E}_1 and {\mathcal E}_2.
